name: Agriculture
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2050, 130,000 ha of degraded terriorities will have been restored through agroforestry and silvopastoral systems based on the amount of international support received. Seeking the restoration of degraded lands contributes to adaptation and mitigation in degraded zones of the country (64, 126). (Conditional)

name: Agriculture
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2025, the National Climate Change Plan for the Agriculture Sector (PNCCSA) will have been updated and begun implementation. This involves updating and improving the current PNCCSA. The goal is to be a sector that is low in greenhouse gas emissions, plus adaptative and resilient, that is involved in food security of population for climate change and climate risk management (64, 126).

name: Agriculture
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2025, an agro-climate information system for the agriculture sector will have been created, starting with the establishment of agro-hydro-meterological stations, a climate data center and participative technical tables started up. The information generated will support capacity and communication strategies for specific key actors, with a goal to guarantee the adoption of new measures for final users. Maximizing the yield/performance of the production systems and of each individual process will be sought (64, 126).

name: Agriculture
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2050, 130,000 ha of degraded terriorities will have been restored through agroforestry and silvopastoral systems based on the amount of international support received. Seeking the restoration of degraded lands contributes to adaptation and mitigation in degraded zones of the country (64, 126). (Conditional)

name: Agriculture
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2025, the National Climate Change Plan for the Agriculture Sector (PNCCSA) will have been updated and begun implementation. This involves updating and improving the current PNCCSA. The goal is to be a sector that is low in greenhouse gas emissions, plus adaptative and resilient, that is involved in food security of population for climate change and climate risk management (64, 126).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Marine-coastal systems: By 2025, Panama will have a Technical Climate Change Guide for the Marine-Coastal Systems Sector with adaptation and mitigation components. National committment, centered in integrated management of coastal marine resources, with a focus on climate change risk management and prevention. Seeks to integrate adaptation planning in the regulartory framework and in existing planning instruments, principally implementing Nature-based Solutions (NbS) (56, 126).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Marine-coastal systems: By 2025, Panama will have developed the Technical Manual for Restoration of Degraded Mangrove Areas. Seeks to strengthen knowledge about the process of restoration of impacted mangrove areas and coastal marine wetlands, which contribute enormously to the sequestration and storage of carbon as well as are a fundamental pilar to reduce the impacts of sea level rise and the water quality of the oceans (56, 126).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Resilient human settlements: Communities have adaptative capacity to the adverse effects of increased climate change, reduced vulnerability, and measures to manage established disaster risk (66).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2025, the National Climate Change Plan for the Agriculture Sector (PNCCSA) will have been updated and begun implementation. This involves updating and improving the current PNCCSA. The goal is to be a sector that is low in greenhouse gas emissions, plus adaptative and resilient, that is involved in food security of population for climate change and climate risk management (64, 126).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Losses and damages: By 2025, the System for Compilation and Evaluation of Damages Platform (SIRED) will be improved, expanded and strengthened to include slow-onset events. Slow-onset events that SIRED will be expanded to include are those like desertification and degradation of soils and forests, loss of biodiversity, salinization, sea level rise and ocean acidification (128).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2022, the rule for the Evaluation of Environment Impact Studies will have been updated and will incorporate climate risk management, adaptation measures and reduction of the carbon footprint of infrastructure projects. This consists of updating Executive Decree 123 from 2009, the methdology for analysis of environmental management, the elements, aspects and variables that can cause global warming, considering climate change as a vector that introduces environmental changes (72, 125).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Sustainable agriculture, ranching and aquaculture: By 2025, an agro-climate information system for the agriculture sector will have been created, starting with the establishment of agro-hydro-meterological stations, a climate data center and participative technical tables started up. The information generated will support capacity and communication strategies for specific key actors, with a goal to guarantee the adoption of new measures for final users. Maximizing the yield/performance of the production systems and of each individual process will be sought (64, 126).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Circular economy: By 2025, Panama will have developed its National Climate Change Plan for the Circular Economy for the long term and until 2025, and will have 10% progress in implementation. This will enable expansion of the planning tools to reduce the vulnerability of the sector to climate change effects, with the objective being to integrate adaptation planning in the regulatory framework and in existing planning tools (76, 127).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Resilient human settlements: Communities have adaptative capacity to the adverse effects of increased climate change, reduced vulnerability, and measures to manage established disaster risk (66).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: MRV for risk management, monitoring and evaluation: By 2025, Panama commits to establish and advance a National Climate Transparency Platform. The management and monitoring platform of the actions that lead us to carbon neutrality and sustainable development, that is low in emissions and resilient, will have the following components: National GHG System, National Mitigation Actions Registry, National Adaptation Monitoring and Evaluation System, National Means of Implementation Registry (128).

name: Economy-wide
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2025, Panama will have integrated a climate change dimension in public investment projects through implementation of the "Technical Climate Change Guide for Infrastructure Investment Projects." The objective is to promote a complete list of relevant adaptation solution measures, to implement them and to oversee them. Implementation of the technical guide to public investment projects will help to understand the climate risks and the mitigation and adaptation processes to consider before financing and carrying out a project (72, 125).

name: Economy-wide
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2022, the rule for the Evaluation of Environment Impact Studies will have been updated and will incorporate climate risk management, adaptation measures and reduction of the carbon footprint of infrastructure projects. This consists of updating Executive Decree 123 from 2009, the methdology for analysis of environmental management, the elements, aspects and variables that can cause global warming, considering climate change as a vector that introduces environmental changes (72, 125).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2025, the Eco-Label Executive Decree will be updated. This is modernizing, restructing and validating Executive Decree N. 100 from 2008, which regulates the certification of environmentally-clean products and services (76, 127).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2025, the Circular Economy Center will be functioning. This integrates the Industrial Syndicate of Panama, the Ministry of the Environment and the National Private Business Council for an environmentally-friendly productive model (76, 127).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2025, metrics and indicators for monitoring the country's advances will have been generated. The metrics and indicators will align with the sustainable development model, helping to improve competitivity and at the same time generating an economy with fewer emissions and better resource management (76, 127).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2025, the 'Reduce Your Corporate Footprint' will have been developed and be functioning, with at least 100 organizations registered and reporting their carbon or hydrological footprint. Managing the corporate carbon footprint of public and private organizations serves as a tool to guide sustainable economic recuperation in accordance with climate integrity (76, 127).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2025, Panama will have developed its National Climate Change Plan for the Circular Economy for the long term and until 2025, and will have 10% progress in implementation. This will enable expansion of the planning tools to reduce the vulnerability of the sector to climate change effects, with the objective being to integrate adaptation planning in the regulatory framework and in existing planning tools (76, 127).

name: Economy-wide
title: Circular economy: By 2022, the Environmental Audits and Management Plans rule will have been updated to include disaster risk management, adaptation measures and carbon footprint reduction. Update will be of the Executive Decree No 57 from 2004, which regulates the evaluation process for environmental audits and management (76, 127).

name: Energy
title: Energy: By 2025, Panama will have a National Climate Change Plan for the energy sector with a mitigation component and one adaptation component. Input for the planning and improvement of the operation of the national energy system, including all energy sources, transformation of the system and transportation are to contribute to climate resilience and a route to transition to carbon neutrality (44, 124)

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity: By 2025,the Climate Change Guide for the Biodiversity Sector with a focus on adaptation and mitigation will have its design, construction and preliminary implementation actions, constructed with technical support from the Protected Areas and Biodiversity Directorate and from the Coasts and Seas Directorate. This will represent a planning instrument for adaptation through implementation of measures that reduce the impacts on biodiversity with implemention of strategies that reduce the vulnerability and fragmentation of habit, increasing resilience to extreme climate events, and at the same time protecting carbon reserves (59, 126).

name: Environment
title: Integrated management of watersheds: By 2022, the Panama Canal Authority will have completed the development of the Indicative Plan for Environmental Land Use Planning for the Panama Canal watershed. The plan seeks to the guide economic activities and environmental protection and conservation in the Panama Canal watershed, and achieve harmonization between applicable environmental management tools (51, 124).

name: Environment
title: Circular economy: By 2022, the Environmental Audits and Management Plans rule will have been updated to include disaster risk management, adaptation measures and carbon footprint reduction. Update will be of the Executive Decree No 57 from 2004, which regulates the evaluation process for environmental audits and management (76, 127).

name: Environment
title: Integrated management of watersheds: By 2025, Panama will have a "Climate Change Plan for Integrated Management of Watersheds" that includes adaptation and mitigation components. Seeks adaptation of watersheds with an emphasis on nature-based solutions. At the same time, the plan seeks emission mitigation through reforestation, soil restoration, conservation of carbon-reserve forests, and sustainable management of forests to increase carbon sequestration (51, 124)

name: Environment
title: Integrated management of watersheds: By 2022, the Panama Canal Authority will have completed the development of the Indicative Plan for Environmental Land Use Planning for the Panama Canal watershed. The plan seeks to the guide economic activities and environmental protection and conservation in the Panama Canal watershed, and achieve harmonization between applicable environmental management tools (51, 124).

name: Health
title: Public health: By 2025, Panama will have developed a "National Climate Change Plan for the Health Sector with mitigation and adaptation components." This would allow for the expansion of planning tools to reduce the vulnerability of the population focusing on strengthening epidemiological monitoring systems with climate and environmental risks that permits monitoring of emerging diseases related to climate change, and at the same time would contribute to the reduction of emissions in an indirect way through the implementation of diverse adaptation measures (68, 125).

name: Transport
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2025, Panama will have a "National Climate Change Plan for the Infrastructure Sector" with mitigation and adaptation components. Panama proposes a vision to develop infrastructure resistent to the impacts of climate change in multiple scopes: drip irrigation, hydraulics to manage floods, potable water, sewers, ports, highways, bridges, airports, and green buildings (72, 125)

name: Urban
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2025, Panama will have a "National Climate Change Plan for the Infrastructure Sector" with mitigation and adaptation components. Panama proposes a vision to develop infrastructure resistent to the impacts of climate change in multiple scopes: drip irrigation, hydraulics to manage floods, potable water, sewers, ports, highways, bridges, airports, and green buildings (72, 125)

name: Urban
title: Resilient human settlements: By 2025, Panama will have developed the "Technical Climate Change Guide for Human Settlements" with mitigation and adaptation components. The plan seeks to increase the resilience of human settlements in the country and strengthen the participation of key actors to plan, finance, implement, monitor and inform strategic adaptation processes and to communicate adaptation knowledge, taking into considering the benefits for mitigation (66, 124).

name: Water
title: Sustainable infrastructure: By 2025, Panama will have a "National Climate Change Plan for the Infrastructure Sector" with mitigation and adaptation components. Panama proposes a vision to develop infrastructure resistent to the impacts of climate change in multiple scopes: drip irrigation, hydraulics to manage floods, potable water, sewers, ports, highways, bridges, airports, and green buildings (72, 125)

name: Water
title: Integrated Water Management Planning: “The kingdom has limited reserves of exploitable non-renewable groundwater and low recharge rates (2.8 bcm in Arabian Shield) due to arid conditions. The Saudi National Water Strategy 2030 aims to work towards addressing all the key challenges, leveraging previous and on-going studies, and reform the water and wastewater sector to ensure sustainable development of water resources while providing affordable high-quality services. Strategic programs and initiatives include laws and regulations, management, innovation and capacity building, and service quality.” (p. 8)

name: Agriculture
title: Food Security: "A sustainable modern agriculture supported by new and innovative technologies across all food production supply and value chains, and by skilled and qualified human resources and integrated with the Blue Economy and Seychelles Strategic Plan 2015" (6, 17-18).

name: Agriculture
title: Food Security: "Integrate of early warning systems in agriculture" (18).

name: Agriculture
title: Food Security: "Invest in research and innovation to strengthen Seychelles’ climate resilience" (18).

name: Agriculture
title: Long-term vision - Food Security: "Much has been made of the “blue economy” and for islands that would seem to be a logical consideration. Seychelles needs to fast-track its blue-economy ambition into action so that it can develop innovative and additive links with the Seychelles Strategic Plan 2015 which is in its closing formulation. For island states, it is too short-sighted in terms of climate change and island development to orchestrate land use plans without due consideration of the primary engine ~ the blue economy" (12).

name: Agriculture
title: Water Security: "Fully integrated approach to water security that addresses issues such as ecosystem health, waste management, water treatment and supply, sewage, agriculture, etc" (6, 18).

name: Economy-wide
title: Critical Infrastructure: "Climate change adaptation to be mainstreamed in all sectors with critical infrastructure" (6, 17).

name: Energy
title: Long-term vision - Energy Security: "Mechanised transport is essential given the terrain of Seychelles. This currently relies on fossil-fuelled vehicles and infrastructure that is degraded. Both require upgrading as these are critical and underpin all other sectors ~ moving people to school, work and shops. The departments responsible for road maintenance and repair in case of flooding, erosion and landslides collaborate to some degree to deal with crises, but a strengthening of cooperation between them in term of troubleshooting and planning would be desirable (e.g. Seychelles Land Transport Agency, the Department of Transport, Department of Risk and Disaster Management and the Ministry of Environment, Energy and Climate Change)" (13).

name: Energy
title: Energy Security: "Strengthened cooperation between Government entities" (6).

name: Energy
title: Long-term vision - Energy Security: "There is a need to keep the options for diversifying electricity sources under continual review, whilst exploring more opportunities for the application of renewable energy technologies and strategies for using waste as an energy form. Commensurate with this, the distribution grid needs to maintain flexibility, and plans engaged to move critical infrastructure out of flooding/storm surge risk areas. Whilst the introduction of renewables is a usual early thought that has to be cautioned with detailed feasibility studies, innovations are possible, though require well-programmed research" (13).

name: Energy

Whilst the introduction of renewables is a usual early thought that has to be cautioned with detailed feasibility studies, innovations are possible, though require well-programmed research" (13).

title: Energy Security: "More resilient energy base with greater innovation of renewable energy where practicable" (6).

title: Energy Security: "Efficient fuel-based land transport and more use of electric vehicles charged with renewable energy technology" (6).

name: Tourism
title: Long-term vision - Tourism: "The key economic sector is Tourism and this sector requires nimble, adaptive responses, particularly where its success is predicated on proximity to the coastal or island areas... Adaptive responses may include expanding marine tourism (yachts, ocean-based experiences) and mountain tourism (away from the coast)" (12).

title: Sustainable tourism: "Minimising negative impacts of tourism on environment (and society) generally" (14).

name: Tourism
title: Sustainable tourism: "addressing climate change through training of tourism environmental representatives, training of the Seychelles Tourism Board in sustainable tourism development and training of environmental conservationists" (14).

name: Transport
title: Critical Infrastructure: "Planning process for all new developments, with associated improvements in the building codes and their rigorous enforcement" (6, 17).

name: Transport
title: Long-term vision - Critical Infrastructure: "Another essential component of overall country resilience to climate change is recognising and planning for Critical Infrastructure, particularly roads, ports, government buildings, energy generation, and water and sewerage management systems. Building capacity in managing the country’s critical infrastructure requires clear linkages between responsible Government entities, a responsive education and awareness programme targeting infrastructure users, supported by appropriate research, and followed by reflexive monitoring" (12).

name: Transport
title: Long-term vision - Energy Security: "Mechanised transport is essential given the terrain of Seychelles. This currently relies on fossil-fuelled vehicles and infrastructure that is degraded. Both require upgrading as these are critical and underpin all other sectors ~ moving people to school, work and shops. The departments responsible for road maintenance and repair in case of flooding, erosion and landslides collaborate to some degree to deal with crises, but a strengthening of cooperation between them in term of troubleshooting and planning would be desirable (e.g. Seychelles Land Transport Agency, the Department of Transport, Department of Risk and Disaster Management and the Ministry of Environment, Energy and Climate Change)" (13).

name: Transport
title: Energy Security: "Efficient fuel-based land transport and more use of electric vehicles charged with renewable energy technology" (6).

name: Urban
title: Critical Infrastructure: "Planning process for all new developments, with associated improvements in the building codes and their rigorous enforcement" (6, 17).

name: Urban
title: Long-term vision - Critical Infrastructure: "Another essential component of overall country resilience to climate change is recognising and planning for Critical Infrastructure, particularly roads, ports, government buildings, energy generation, and water and sewerage management systems. Building capacity in managing the country’s critical infrastructure requires clear linkages between responsible Government entities, a responsive education and awareness programme targeting infrastructure users, supported by appropriate research, and followed by reflexive monitoring" (12).

name: Urban
title: Waste: "Waste managed according to strict hierarchy and waste policy fully implemented" (6).

name: Urban
title: Waste: "Exploration of relevant potential science and technology innovations" (6).

name: Urban
title: Long-term vision - Waste: "The conventional waste hierarchy (reduce, re-use, recycle) should be implemented fully and the use of organic waste for soil improvement promoted" (13).

name: Water
title: Critical Infrastructure: "Planning process for all new developments, with associated improvements in the building codes and their rigorous enforcement" (6, 17).

name: Water
title: Long-term vision - Critical Infrastructure: "Another essential component of overall country resilience to climate change is recognising and planning for Critical Infrastructure, particularly roads, ports, government buildings, energy generation, and water and sewerage management systems. Building capacity in managing the country’s critical infrastructure requires clear linkages between responsible Government entities, a responsive education and awareness programme targeting infrastructure users, supported by appropriate research, and followed by reflexive monitoring" (12).

name: Water
title: Water Security: "Increase strorage capacity by building a dam" (18).

name: Water
title: Long-term vision - Water Security: "particularly considering issues of storage and distribution, requires urgent attention and needs to take into account projected population growth, whilst reducing demand for treated water, using more rainwater, improving efficiency of the distribution system, and improving water storage capacity. Increasing water demand from the residential, commercial, agriculture, and tourism sectors is exacerbated by changes in rainfall patterns and a limited water storage capacity" (13).

name: Water
title: Water Security: "Fully integrated approach to water security that addresses issues such as ecosystem health, waste management, water treatment and supply, sewage, agriculture, etc" (6, 18).

name: Water
title: Water Security: "Improving water resource management" (18).

name: Water
title: Long-term vision - Water Security: "particularly considering issues of storage and distribution, requires urgent attention and needs to take into account projected population growth, whilst reducing demand for treated water, using more rainwater, improving efficiency of the distribution system, and improving water storage capacity. Increasing water demand from the residential, commercial, agriculture, and tourism sectors is exacerbated by changes in rainfall patterns and a limited water storage capacity" (13).

name: Agriculture
title: Food security: "Singapore's main strategy is to diversify sources for food supply resilience. This is supplemented by limited local production of key food items and rice stockpiling." (p. 5)

name: Agriculture
title: Food security: "The Singapore Government encourages food security research and development"

name: Agriculture
title: Food security: "The Singapore Government… incentivises the adoption of technology to increase productivity of local farms"

name: Coastal Zone
title: Protecting the coastline: "A range of technologies are also being deployed to enhance coastal infrastructure at specific locations for the long term, while continued efforts are made to protect Singapore’s critical logistics supply infrastructure (located in coastal regions) against the risk of increased flooding." (p. 6)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Infrastructure resilience: "For energy and telecommunication services, private operators are required to meet performance standards and ensure network resilience, including through monitoring and maintenance. The Singapore Government constantly reviews and revises design codes, regulations and policies to account for new information and the latest climate projections." (p. 5)

name: Energy
title: Infrastructure resilience: "For energy and telecommunication services, private operators are required to meet performance standards and ensure network resilience, including through monitoring and maintenance. The Singapore Government constantly reviews and revises design codes, regulations and policies to account for new information and the latest climate projections." (p. 5)

name: Environment
title: Safeguarding biodiversity: "Singapore will continue efforts to safeguard its biodiversity despite an urban environment. The array of natural ecosystems (including evergreen rain forest, mangroves, freshwater streams, freshwater swamp forest, coral reefs and mudflats) will continue to be conserved, with targeted programs for habitat enhancement and species recovery where required." (p. 7)

name: Environment
title: In 2015, the SGBioAtlas smartphone application was launched to engage and allow members of the public to easily report sightings of biodiversity (e.g. birds, butterflies) in their daily lives. The data collected will help Singapore monitor its biodiversity and develop biodiversity management plans

name: Health
title: Public Health: "A surveillance programme – anchored in human case, virus, mosquito and weather monitoring – has been established for the early warning of increased risks. Contingency plans are also in place to deal with the anticipated impacts of climate change (including during haze episodes and heat waves), which result in short-term surges in healthcare demand." (p. 6)

name: Transport
title: Infrastructure resilience: "To protect critical transport infrastructure from flood risks, flood barriers have been installed at subway stations that may be affected, with ongoing work to do so for the remaining ones." (p. 5)

name: Water
title: Addressing flood risks: "Commercial, industrial, institutional and residential developments and redevelopments greater than or equal to 0.2 hectares are required to implement onsite storm water detention measures to reduce the peak discharge into the public drainage system." (p. 6)

name: Water
title: Enhancing water security: "Singapore plans to expand NEWater and desalination capacity to meet up to 80% of its water demand in 2060. Variable salinity8 technology can be used to help expand Singapore’s water catchment to up to 90% of its land area by tapping on the streams and rivulets near the shoreline." (p. 6)

name: Water
title: Enhancing water security: "Singapore plans to expand NEWater and desalination capacity to meet up to 80% of its water demand in 2060. Variable salinity8 technology can be used to help expand Singapore’s water catchment to up to 90% of its land area by tapping on the streams and rivulets near the shoreline." (p. 6)

title: Diversify sources for food supply resilience;|Encourage Food security research and development, and incentivises the adoption of technology to increase productivity and resilience of local farms.

name: Urban
title: Building Control Act

name: Urban
title: Constantly review and revises design codes, regulations and policies to account for new information and the latest climate projections.

name: Water
title: A robust, diversified water supply system through “The Four National Taps“: namely, local catchment water, imported water, NEWater7 and desalinated water;|Expand NEWater and desalination capacity to meet up to 80% of its water demand in 2060;|Variable salinity technology can be used to help expand Singapore‘s water catchment to up to 90% of its land area.

name: Agriculture
title: "To make food supply more resilient, Singapore is pursuing three strategies, namely: 1) Diversification of import sources; 2) Grow local; and 3) Grow overseas." (p. 23)

name: Agriculture
title: "In particular, Singapore has set an ambitious target for local food production. By 2030, Singapore aims to meet 30% of Singapore’s nutritional needs with food produced in Singapore. To do so, the Singapore Government will support the local agri-food industry to adopt innovative solutions and raise productivity. This includes building an R&D ecosystem to enhance urban food production, develop production technologies for alternative proteins, as well as strengthen food safety capabilities and technologies. Farms can tap on the Agriculture Productivity Fund (APF) to co-fund systems to better control environmental variables and boost production capabilities, as well as to leverage technology to produce food sustainably." (p. 24-25)

name: Coastal Zone
title: "Singapore is also conserving and restoring its mangrove forests. Mangroves help to dissipate waves and trap sediment, potentially serving as a flexible form of coastal defence while reducing erosion." (p. 22)

name: Coastal Zone
title: New critical infrastructure, such as the Tuas Port and Changi Airport Terminal 5, will have platforms raised even higher, to at least five metres above the SHD. These various coastal protection measures will not only help overcome the challenges of sea level rise, but also present new exciting opportunities for new green and blue community spaces for Singaporeans. (p. 21)

name: Coastal Zone
title: "Singapore will be naturalising more waterways and waterbodies in its gardens and parks. Coastal and riverine parks will also incorporate designs such as floodplains to protect coastal and low-lying areas from sea level rise or flooding." (p. 22)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Centre for Climate Research Singapore (CCRS), established in Singapore in 2013, is one of the few dedicated centres in the region that focuses on research in tropical weather and climate... CCRS will also undertake a National Sea Level Research programme to develop more robust projections of sea level rise, and seek to enhance understanding of long-term sea level rise and its variability, regional patterns and extreme weather events...CCRS will also cooperate with regional counterparts to study in further detail how climate change is affecting the region. In addition, the Meteorological Service Singapore/CCRS will work closely with the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) Regional Office for Asia and the South-West Pacific in Singapore to implement WMO’s programmes and capacity development initiatives in Asia and the South-West Pacific" (p. 20)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Centre for Climate Research Singapore (CCRS), established in Singapore in 2013, is one of the few dedicated centres in the region that focuses on research in tropical weather and climate... CCRS will also undertake a National Sea Level Research programme to develop more robust projections of sea level rise, and seek to enhance understanding of long-term sea level rise and its variability, regional patterns and extreme weather events...CCRS will also cooperate with regional counterparts to study in further detail how climate change is affecting the region. In addition, the Meteorological Service Singapore/CCRS will work closely with the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) Regional Office for Asia and the South-West Pacific in Singapore to implement WMO’s programmes and capacity development initiatives in Asia and the South-West Pacific" (p. 20)

name: Environment
title: "Singapore will conserve more native plants and animals by carrying out recovery plans for over 70 more animals and plant species, enhancing 30 hectares of forest, marine and coastal habitats, and restoring ecological habitats in at least half of its gardens, parks and streetscapes by 2030. Singapore will also be planting one million more trees across the island by 2030." (p. 24)

name: Transport
title: "Singapore is strengthening the resilience of its critical services. For example, the drainage system at Changi Airport which is located along the coast, is being significantly upgraded to protect the airport against flood risks. To protect the train network and commuters, flood barriers are installed at the entrances of underground Mass Rapid Transit train stations in low-lying areas." (p. 23)

name: Transport
title: New critical infrastructure, such as the Tuas Port and Changi Airport Terminal 5, will have platforms raised even higher, to at least five metres above the SHD. These various coastal protection measures will not only help overcome the challenges of sea level rise, but also present new exciting opportunities for new green and blue community spaces for Singaporeans. (p. 21)

name: Urban
title: "Singapore will be naturalising more waterways and waterbodies in its gardens and parks. Coastal and riverine parks will also incorporate designs such as floodplains to protect coastal and low-lying areas from sea level rise or flooding." (p. 22)

name: Water
title: Singapore will continue to explore innovative approaches to coastal protection measures, which may include a combination of conventional engineering solutions such as sea walls, tidal gates and pumping stations, and nature-based solutions. "In view of this, the Singapore Government has set up a Coastal and Flood Protection Fund, with an initial funding of S$5 billion, to support the substantial capital outlay. These are necessary to build up Singapore’s resilience against climate change and safeguard its future in a fiscally sustainable manner" (p. 22)

name: Water
title: "An additional S$190 million will be spent in 2020 to upgrade and maintain drains. Singapore will need to continually invest and manage its infrastructure to deal with the effects from climate change." (p. 22)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community-based vulnerability mapping, adaptation planning and management approach (tied to direct access to financing for community-based resilience-building projects) on a whole of island basis;|Build national capacity to facilitate direct access to international climate change financing including the Green Climate Fund so as to ensure that financing for climate resilience is country-owned and directed towards priority national needs and community-based adaptation plans and mitigation measures.

name: Water
title: To ensure adequate water supply for the growing population of the city a robust and well enforced Integrated Water Resource Management strategy and programme needs to be put in place. |

name: Coastal Zone
title: “Implementation of Solomon Islands National Ocean Policy.” (p. 19)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Review and revise the NAPA and Ministry of Environment, Climate Change, Disaster Management and Meteorology (MECDM) Strategic Plan and develop a National Adaptation Plan (NAP) to address climate change over the short, medium and long term. The NAP shall address long term adaptation to climate change and short-term disaster risk reduction in relation to climate variability and contain an implementation plan.” (p. 17)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Develop a Resilient Development Framework for climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction at national, provincial and community levels” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Strengthen the capacity and partnerships of national and provincial government agencies, national institutions, NGOs, churches and all Solomon Island communities to integrate Kastom knowledge in vulnerability and adaptation (V&A) and disaster risk reduction (DRR) assessments for different sectors and geographic areas.” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Expand the national census portfolio and integrate questions to obtain data on extreme events, vulnerability and adaptation. Collaborate with and utilise data from other relevant sources to address features of risk.” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Provide support to ministries, provincial governments and civil society organizations, including faith-based and private sector organisations, to review and revise their corporate plans, sector programs and strategies to include measures to assess vulnerability of sectors and identify and implement adaptation and disaster risk reduction strategies and actions.” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Develop a coordinated and geo-referenced national information system covering livelihood assets – natural, human, financial, social and physical capital – that can be used to identify sensitivities to climate change, adaptive capacity, and key strategies covering vulnerable groups, natural resources and environmental management and disaster risk reduction and management.” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: “Build capacity, plan and implement ecosystem-based vulnerability assessments and adaptation programs and actions including, inter-alia, implementation of the protected areas legislation and regulations, low-impact logging strategies, marine ecosystem management.” (p. 18)

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

(p. 19)

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Cross-Cutting Area

name: Social Development

title: “The country will strengthen surveillance of infectious diseases and their link to climate and environment-related factors amid the COVID-19 pandemic.” (p. 10)

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "To have formulated, adopted and started the implementation of a National Adaptation Plan for Agriculture by 2020" (19).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "To have designed and implemented, by 2025, risk transfer instruments, such as climate index-based insurances and the Emergency Agriculture Fund (FAE, for its acronym in Spanish)" (20).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "To have, by 2025, comprehensive information systems for adaptive management in agriculture for the public and private sector, and to have promoted research programs on dryland agriculture, vegetable and fruit crops, forage crops and pastures that better adapt to climate variability" (20).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "To have, by 2025, comprehensive information systems for adaptive management in agriculture for the public and private sector, and to have promoted research programs on dryland agriculture, vegetable and fruit crops, forage crops and pastures that better adapt to climate variability" (20).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "By 2025, 95% of the agricultural area is under land use and management plans, including plans to reduce erosion and preserve organic matter in croplands, the productivity and water storage capacity have improved, and the risk of erosion during extreme rainfall events has been reduced" (20).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "Adoption, by 2025, of good practices of natural land management and management of breeding herds in livestock production in an area ranging from 1,000,000 to 3,000,000 ha (10-30% of grasslands), including the supply of forage, regenerative management and the addition of supplements in times of drought, enhancing extension and livestock innovation mechanisms for that purpose" (19).

name: Agriculture
title: Agricultural sector: "By 2025, 100% of the area of the shelter and shade forests plantations –which provide shelter and well-being for animals, especially in adverse weather situations– has been preserved (78,000 ha)" (20).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Coastal areas: "To have formulated, adopted and started the implementation of a National Adaptation Plan for Coastal Areas by 2020" (19).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Coastal areas: "To have mapped by 2020 the coastal vulnerability of the River Plate and the Atlantic Ocean to climate change and variability" (19).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Coastal areas: "To have an adaptive management strategy in 20% of the coastal line of the Uruguay River, the River Plate and the Atlantic Ocean by 2025, prioritizing the most vulnerable stretches" (19).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Coastal areas: "To have, by 2020, a system for monitoring and assessing adaptation actions in the six coastal departments in coordination with institutions dealing with coastal areas" (19).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate services: "To have, by 2025, a comprehensive system for designing and managing climate services for decision-making in the public and/or private sector for the relevant industries" (20).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate services: "To have, by 2025, a radar network in the country –to complement the existing regional network–, a radio sounding station and a national telemetric rain gauge network that will help monitor flash floods, among other events" (20).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Agricultural sector: "Adoption, by 2025, of good practices of natural land management and management of breeding herds in livestock production in an area ranging from 1,000,000 to 3,000,000 ha (10-30% of grasslands), including the supply of forage, regenerative management and the addition of supplements in times of drought, enhancing extension and livestock innovation mechanisms for that purpose" (19).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Cities, Infrastructure and Land-use planning: "To have implemented by 2020 a Guide for the Preparation of Land-use Planning Instruments, which includes a climate change and variability adaptation component?" (19).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Cities, Infrastructure and Land-use planning: "Adaptation measures will have been promoted by 2025 in at least 30% of the cities with over 5,000 residents to address vulnerabilities and improve their adaptive capacities" (19).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Cities, Infrastructure and Land-use planning: "At least seven departments will have regional, departmental or municipal local climate change and variability adaptation plans by 2025" (19).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "To have, by 2020, six regional risk-management plans (covering the entire country), those taking into account climate change and variability, with focus in urban and rural population depending on specific vulnerability characteristics" (18).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "To have, by 2025, departmental risk-management instruments that take into account climate change and variability in every department of Uruguay" (18).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "Departmental risk-management instruments consider at least 25% of municipal areas, and include the participation and perspective of the third level of government by 2025" (19).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "Ongoing training on climate change and climate risk management for decision-makers and the general population by 2020" (19).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "At least 30 flood cities have maps showing the flood hazards of drainages, riverbanks and/or rising sea levels and storm surges by 2025" (19).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Health care: "To have formulated by 2025 a diagnosis of the response capacity and the infrastructure of health care services and centers to extreme weather events in at least four departments" (18).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Disaster Risk Reduction: "At least eight flood cities will have a flood early warning system by 2025" (19).

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Health care: "An early-warning system for extreme temperature events (heat and cold waves) will have been developed, and it will have been implemented in at least two departments by 2020" (18).

name: Economy-wide
title: Agricultural sector: "To have designed and implemented, by 2025, risk transfer instruments, such as climate index-based insurances and the Emergency Agriculture Fund (FAE, for its acronym in Spanish)" (20).

name: Energy
title: Energy: "To have formulated, adopted and started the implementation of a National Energy Adaptation Plan by 2015" (20).

name: Energy
title: Energy: "To have diversified, by 2025, the power grid sources, thus reducing the vulnerabilities resulting from the dependence of hydropower generation on climate conditions, with at least 1,700 installed MW from at least three non-traditional sources, and with the option of power accumulation plants" (20).

name: Environment
title: Agricultural sector: "By 2025, 95% of the agricultural area is under land use and management plans, including plans to reduce erosion and preserve organic matter in croplands, the productivity and water storage capacity have improved, and the risk of erosion during extreme rainfall events has been reduced" (20).

name: Environment
title: Agricultural sector: "By 2025, 100% of the area of the shelter and shade forests plantations –which provide shelter and well-being for animals, especially in adverse weather situations– has been preserved (78,000 ha)" (20).

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity and ecosystems: "The management plans of at least six protected areas will include climate change and variability considerations by 2025" (19).

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity and ecosystems: "By 2025, 100% of the native forest area will be protected, with the option of increasing said area by 5%, especially in water resource environmental protection areas, attempting to revert degradation processes" (19).

name: Environment
title: Water resources: "To have formulated, adopted and implemented by 2025 three integrated basin management plans that consider climate change and variability" (19).

name: Health
title: Health care: "To have, by 2020, a Climate Change and Health Training Program for the staff working in the health care sector" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "To have identified, formulated and implemented by 2025 Environmental Health indicators associated with climate change and health status of the population, contemplating information about the disease burden linked to climate change" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "An 'Assessment for the establishment of models to predict the behavior of vector-borne diseases and zoonosis linked to climate change' will be under development by 2025" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "To have formulated, adopted and implemented a National Plan for the prevention of diseases transmissible by climate-change sensitive vectors by 2025" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "To have formulated, adopted and started the implementation of a National Health Adaptation Plan by 2015" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "An early-warning system for extreme temperature events (heat and cold waves) will have been developed, and it will have been implemented in at least two departments by 2020" (18).

name: Health
title: Health care: "To have formulated by 2025 a diagnosis of the response capacity and the infrastructure of health care services and centers to extreme weather events in at least four departments" (18).

name: Social Development
title: Social policies: "To make available, by 2025, georeferenced information of social vulnerabilities associated to adverse climatic events, adopting human rights and gender perspectives and looking at childhood, population below the poverty line and/or indigence, homeless people, older adults, disabled people, afro-descendants, migrants and rural population" (18).

name: Social Development
title: Social policies: "To have relocated, by 2025, between 3500 and 6000 of the households in flood or contaminated zones identified through the National Relocation Plan and other national and departmental instruments, enabling access to basic services to relocated population and assigning new uses to give a different significance to flood zones" (18).

name: Tourism
title: Tourism: "The Green Seal Certification, which includes different actions to achieve a more resilient performance of buildings, through the use of appropriate design and materials to be better prepared in the face of extreme weather events, the implementation of best practices and the installation of devices to efficiently manage and harness rainwater, and prevent erosion, will have been awarded to between 4% and 10% of tourist accommodation services by 2025" (20).

name: Urban
title: Tourism: "The Green Seal Certification, which includes different actions to achieve a more resilient performance of buildings, through the use of appropriate design and materials to be better prepared in the face of extreme weather events, the implementation of best practices and the installation of devices to efficiently manage and harness rainwater, and prevent erosion, will have been awarded to between 4% and 10% of tourist accommodation services by 2025" (20).

name: Coastal Zone
title: Ecosystem Based Approaches-- "Support ecosystem function and services through action and planning by: Prioritizing action incorporating threats and solutions from the ridge to the reef of island communities (e.g. waste management)" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Enhance efficiency and effectiveness of adaptation action and design action... in specific sites: Adaptation, appropriate to local communities, being a research priority for all actors, including scientific research, farmer-based trials, traditional indicators and observation systems and demonstration sites" (9).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction: "Formal and non-formal education programs and curriculums incorporating an integrated approach" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community Based Adaptation--"Addresses real, current and priority vulnerabilities through: The community being fully engaged in, participate in and lead vulnerability assessment process in an appropriate language (e.g. colloquial languages, Bislama)" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community Based Adaptation--"Build on and strengthen traditional and customary systems by: Building on and working within traditional knowledge and values so that these systems become more robust, with linkages and synergies with scientific knowledge, thereby avoiding maladaptation" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community Based Adaptation--"Adaptation is owned and driven by communities through: Adaptation implementation plans and actions being developed and driven by the community itself, following its own planning processes that are context specific" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community Based Adaptation--"Adaptation is owned and driven by communities through: Existing community engagement, governance and implementation structures and traditional systems being adhered to and strengthened through adaptation initiatives" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction: "Government agencies, CSOs, private sector and academia taking responsibility for identifying their adaptation priorities and incorporating these into their policy, strategic documents, and budgets to implement adaptation and disaster risk reduction action" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Ecosystem Based Approaches-- "Support ecosystem function and services through action and planning by: Adaptation action building on and incorporating taboos, conservation areas and locally managed areas and protects vulnerable habitats and ecosystems and carbon sinks will be prioritized" (10-11).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Enhance efficiency and effectiveness of adaptation action and design action... in specific sites: Vulnerably assessments and risk mapping using multi-hazard approaches as the basis of all adaptation action, conducted prior to implementation with communities and in a participatory, free and informed way" (9).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Adopt multi-sectoral approaches and address complex impacts through: Considering urban and rural adaptation issues equally and fairly in national adaptation planning and action based on vulnerability criteria" (9).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction: "Strategic documents at all levels including both climate change and disaster risk elements in an integrated and compatible way (e.g. government policies, provincial plans, community strategies, municipal plans, donor project designs, budget frameworks)" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction: "Government agencies, CSOs, private sector and academia taking responsibility for identifying their adaptation priorities and incorporating these into their policy, strategic documents, and budgets to implement adaptation and disaster risk reduction action" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction: "Initiatives endorsed by NAB adhering to an integrated approach" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Community Based Adaptation--"Addresses real, current and priority vulnerabilities through: Community vulnerability assessments and comprehensive profiles being undertaken prior to project implementation" (10).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Enhance efficiency and effectiveness of adaptation action and design action... in specific sites: Adaptation decisions being based on relevant data and information using already available data, statistics and processes" (9).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Enhance efficiency and effectiveness of adaptation action and design action... in specific sites: Data and information on adaptation being shared with and incorporated into centralized systems (eg NAB portal)" (9).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Climate Vulnerability and Multi- Sector Impact Assessment--"Adopt multi-sectoral approaches and address complex impacts through: Considering adaptation information from multiple sectors and knowledge systems to avoid maladaptation that may result from a narrow, single sector adaptation focus" (9).

title: "Land use planning and management" (9)

name: Cross-Cutting Area

title: Ecosystem Based Approaches-- "Support ecosystem function and services through action and planning by: Embedding action and planning within an ecosystem, strengthening all interrelated parts and components (social, biological, economic)" (10).

title: National Adaptation Plan: "Design a national adaptation plan that allows the country to prepare for the climate scenarios and impacts that will occur due to the irresponsibility of the industrialized, polluting countries of the world" (40).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: National Adaptation Plan: "Coordinate actions with all national entities in charge of territorial planning and disaster management, with a prospective vision of the expected increase in temperature for the next 20 years, based on mitigation promises that are consolidated within the framework of the Organization of The United Nations" (40).

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: National Adaptation Plan: "Calculate the costs derived from losses and damages resulting from extreme climatic situations, including insurance and reinsurance for specific sensitive sectors (such as agriculture), which should be added to the ecological debt of industrialized countries" (40).

title: National Adaptation Plan: "Encourage the development of municipal and local adaptation plans for risk management scenarios that directly involve joint responsibility between the State and the People's Power" (40).

title: Future climate prediction: "Reduction of risks due to Climate Variability and Change Climate, in the specific sectors of Water, Agriculture, Energy Health and Disaster, selected by the WMO for the implementation of the Global Framework for Climate Services (GFCS), to which the Venezuelan State would add Biodiversity for its commitment to protected natural spaces" (26).

name: Economy-wide
title: Develop socialism: "Promote and guarantee new production processes and recovery of scientific, ancestral, traditional and popular knowledge, as well as new relations between them, with special attention to the practices of social groups made invisible and discriminated against by capitalism and neocolonialism" (33).

name: Economy-wide
title: Promote an ecosocialist ethic: "Prioritize common interests over individual ones, from a perspective focused on balance with nature and respect for present and future generations" (34).

name: Economy-wide
title: Promote an ecosocialist ethic: "To promote a new scheme of values, oriented to the respect and preservation of nature, that transforms the collective conscience, on the capitalist patterns of production and consumption" (34).

name: Economy-wide
title: Socio-productive alternatives: "Promote environmental conservation practices in socio-productive activity, surpassing the criterion of "economic efficiency" because it is a practice unrelated to rationality in the use of natural resources" (35).

name: Economy-wide
title: Socio-productive alternatives: "Facilitate access to small and medium producers and to associative forms of ownership and production, for their effective insertion in intra-regional value chains, with environmental sustainability" (35).

name: Economy-wide
title: Environmental security: "Fight against the securitization of global environmental problems, to avoid the incorporation of environmental and human issues as issues of "International Security" by the hegemonic powers" (38).

name: Economy-wide
title: Environmental security: "Maintain surveillance of the development of the United Nations Security Council agenda to avoid interference in environmental and human issues, and their treatment as international citizen security issues, which threatens the sovereignty of the peoples" (38).

name: Economy-wide
title: Environmental security: "Strengthen substantive debates on economic, social and environmental issues in all international, regional and multilateral spheres, so that decisions are taken in an inclusive and transparent manner, without neo-colonial orientations by developed countries, promoting the incorporation of the Popular Power and in particular the social movements in these spaces" (38-39).

name: Economy-wide
title: UNFCCC Climate Regime: "Initiate a process of transformation of national legal provisions to guarantee the administration and protection of natural heritage, in the construction of ecosocialism" (39).

name: Economy-wide
title: Develop socialism: "Develop a comprehensive conservation policy, sustainable use, protection and scientific dissemination of the biological diversity and the country's water reservoirs" (33).

name: Environment
title: National Strategy for Biological Diversity: "sovereign exercise of the conservation and sustainable use of Biological Diversity...reducing vulnerability to the multiple adverse effects of Climate Change" (17).

name: Environment

name: Environment
title: Promote an ecosocialist ethic: "Promote and develop a vision of the rights of the Mother Earth, as a representation of the rights of generations present and future, as well as respect for other forms of life" (34).

name: Environment
title: Socio-productive alternatives: "Preserve and manage strategic areas for conservation ... for the vital benefits derived from their conservation and their contribution to supreme social happiness" (35).

name: Environment
title: Conservation and sustainable management: "Promote the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity, in a regional, continental and global framework oriented towards integration, sovereignty and living well" (37).

name: Environment
title: Conservation and sustainable management: "Maintain leadership in international multilateral and regional negotiations, related to the respective environmental sector legal frameworks" (37).

name: Environment
title: "Promote cooperation, at the regional level, for the integrated management of transboundary natural resources. Reinforce cooperation with border countries on issues of environmental management and ecological zones of common interest in accordance with the principles of international law, respecting the sovereignty national. Defend the territorial rights and sovereignty of the Venezuelan State in negotiations related to the administration of marine, submarine and oceanic spaces, as well as the biological diversity present in those spaces" (38).

name: Environment
title: Socio-productive alternatives: "Create ecological urban systems, with architectural designs balanced with natural ecosystems that reduce levels of environmental pollution" (34).

name: Environment
title: Conservation and sustainable management: "Deepen the comprehensive protection of water as a duty, articulated between instances of the Public Power and the Popular Power, making responsible use of it and promoting national and international spaces for discussion on its use and democratization" (37).

name: Environment
title: Conservation and sustainable management: "Protect the country's hydrographic basins and all resources natural resources present in them, promoting their integral management, with special emphasis on those located south of the Orinoco" (37).

name: Transport
