name: Agriculture
title: Urban Agriculture: “Science will be strengthened for the development of the training of scientists in the agricultural area to adapt to climatic conditions.” (p. 98)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security): “Ten (10) legal instruments will be created and applied to implement actions for agroecological production of crops to reduce the toxic load and minimize the impacts of climate change, as well as for the regulation or prohibition of the agricultural use of highly toxic synthetic pesticides.” (p. 93) Action Description: “The legal instruments will be developed at the INSAI headquarters, by the staff of the Directorate of Aggression and Popular Participation and the Legal Consultancy, once a diagnosis of national needs has been made, and the review of public policies and guidelines issued by the MPPAT, regarding climate change and environmental conservation.” (p. 93)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security): “90 “Non-polluting” agroecological systems will be carried out.” (p. 93) Action Description: “Agroecological systems will be developed in conjunction with organized agricultural communities, in rural and urban areas. This action is expected to benefit 90 agricultural communities in obtaining technical knowledge, to increase resilience in the face of climate change.” (p. 93)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security): “50,000 recruitment, training and support activities will be carried out for agroecological or organic production to producers, nationwide. 200,000 farmers are expected to benefit.” (p. 93) Action Description: “The recruitment, training and support activities will be carried out, through visits and inspections by field technicians, at the national level so that producers can adapt to the new climatic variations that are occurring in the present in the future, it is expected to benefit 200,000 farmers.” (p. 93)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security), Cocoa: “The area planted and rehabilitated for cocoa cultivation will be increased with the practice and use of nurseries (sowing). It is intended to contribute to the reduction of the global emission of greenhouse gases and in turn the development of agroecological practices implemented by cocoa farmers will be consolidated.” (p. 95)

name: Agriculture
title: Urban Agriculture: “The National Institute of Agricultural Research of Lines will be re-launched, in order to guarantee the research, planning and multiplication of seeds and materials of new plant genetics for national production, to advance in the rescue of autochthonous seeds of indigenous and Afro-descendant rural origin to through seminary producers linked to the organization of the popular base of popular power to adapt to new climatic conditions.” (p. 98)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security): “20,000 liters of biofertilizers and 20,000 doses of biocontrollers will be produced in the agricultural bio-inputs laboratories.” (p. 93) Action Description: “The production of bio-inputs will be carried out in the INSAI laboratories, to benefit the farmers of the surrounding communities, in order to contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gases caused by Nox compounds.” (p. 93)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security), Cocoa: “The current legal framework for the sustainable development of the cocoa sector will be strengthened by implementing actions to ensure the protection of the cocoa crop (Theobroma cacao L) being highly relevant for agriculture and food security in the face of the impacts of climate change.” (p. 95)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security), Cocoa: “The development of scientific research, training and technology transfer processes will be strengthened as a strategy to contribute to the prevention and optimal care of the cocoa agroecosystem, in order to promote the sustainability and resilience of cocoa cultivation to new climatic conditions.” (p. 95)

name: Agriculture
title: Agriculture (Food Security), Cocoa: “The practice of cocoa culture as an agricultural-social activity will be strengthened, promoting that families who work in this area can demonstrate the performance in production and the quality of the fruit, it is closely related to the use of sustainability strategies with the environmental” (p. 95)

name: Agriculture
title: Urban Agriculture: “The National Recovery Plan, Maintenance of Existing Agricultural Machinery, which is launched by the socialist company Pedro Camejo, will be completed to more effectively execute the actions that will promote the relaunch of the Great AgroVenezuela Mission for the strengthening of national production, guaranteeing the food safety.” (p. 98)

name: Agriculture
title: Urban Agriculture: “The foundations of Popular Power will be consolidated in order to strengthen the great Agrovenezuela mission through good agricultural practices to help the food system and be more resilient to weather conditions.” (p. 98)

name: Agriculture
title: Urban Agriculture: “The spaces of the farmers will be consolidated as established in the Plan of the Homeland for the Supreme Happiness possible, guaranteeing food sovereignty.” (p. 98)

name: Agriculture
title: University Education, Rafael María Baralt National Experimental University (UNERMB) - Research Program -CDCHT: “Research and innovation policies at UNERMB together with the Research Center for the Promotion of Endogenous Development (CIPDE) and the Center for Agrifood and Environmental Research (CIAGROA): 1) 17 lines, research and innovation projects will be developed that have sustainability as an objective to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change; 2) 22 Environmental Brigades will be implemented in university spaces, estimating 1 for each undergraduate and graduate campus to raise awareness about the effects of Climate Change. 3) 50 (Popular Power Base Organizations) afforestation activities will be developed in conjunction with the Tree Mission to form optimal areas for carbon sinks. 4) 1250 sustainability areas will be formed for students, teaching staff, administrative staff and workers of our institution to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change. 5) 2,400 areas of sustainability will be formed for grassroots organizations of popular power to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change. 6) 120 Sustainable Development Training Seminar and the 2030 agenda "Transform Our World" will be held. Dictated by the Research Center for the Promotion of Endogenous Development (CIPDE).” (p. 116-117)

name: Coastal Zone
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Plan for the Planning and Integrated Management of Coastal Zones (POGIZC) of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.” Description: “Within the framework of the approval of the Plan for the Integrated Management and Planning of Coastal Zones (POGIZC) of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and the continuity of activities linked to the 10 Programs for the Integrated Management of Coastal Zones, the aspiration is to in the period 2021 - 2030: 1. Review and update the Conservation and Sustainable Development Policies of the Coastal Zones of Venezuela. 2. Continue the strengthening of the System of Marine-Coastal Protected Areas of Venezuela by creating and improving the processes of planning and integrated management of their territories. 3. Continue and strengthen the Inventory and Characterization of the Sandy Beaches of Venezuela. 4. Continue the reactivation and participation in various spaces for the creation of Alliances: Redparques, Ramsar Convention, UNDP, UNEP, WCPA, GEF, PPD, Inparques, Mintur, Alianza de Montañas (FAO), Andean Mountain Initiative, among others. 5. Strengthening and systematization of the knowledge base, and of the Information Systems for the Integrated Management of Coastal Zones (SIGIZC).” (p. 144)

name: Coastal Zone
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “National Policies for the Conservation and Sustainable Development of Coastal Zones.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030, it is estimated that the Conservation and Sustainable Development Policies of the Coastal Zones of Venezuela will be reviewed and updated, considering, among others, the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the United Nations Framework Convention on the Climate Change, as well as the guidelines on the United Nations Decade on Ecosystem Restoration and the United Nations Decade of Ocean Sciences for Sustainable Development, for which the following will be required: 1. The reactivation of the Working Committee Central of the Coastal Zones (CTCZC), chaired by the Ministry of Popular Power for Ecososcialism. 2. The reactivation and strengthening of the Coastal Zones Work Committees at the State Level (CTZCNE). 3. Generation of a methodological process to carry out the review and update of the National Policies for Conservation and Sustainable Development of Coastal Zones.” (p. 147)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Urban Agriculture: “Science will be strengthened for the development of the training of scientists in the agricultural area to adapt to climatic conditions.” (p. 98)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Agriculture (Food Security), Cocoa: “The development of scientific research, training and technology transfer processes will be strengthened as a strategy to contribute to the prevention and optimal care of the cocoa agroecosystem, in order to promote the sustainability and resilience of cocoa cultivation to new climatic conditions.” (p. 95)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Science and Technology: “The greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory will be updated” (p. 109)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Orinoco Oil Belt Territory Planning Project "Hugo Chávez Frías" (National Strategic Development Zone - ZDEN).” Description: “For the purposes of approval and subsequent execution of the activities identified in the instrument, the following is required: 1. Call for the Public Consultation Process. 2. Holding of Public Consultation Workshops. 3. Evaluation of the proposals and subsequent incorporation in the Draft Decree. 4. Presentation of the Draft Decree for approval by the President of the Republic in the Council of Ministers.” (p. 144-145)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Areas Under the Special Administration Regime (ABRAE) and their Plans of Ordinance and Use Regulations (PORU).” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030 it is estimated to continue strengthening the set of Areas Under Special Administration Regime (ABRAE) of Venezuela, as part of the agreements and commitments assumed before the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) and the Framework Convention of the United Nations on Climate Change. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Declaration of 03 new National Parks. 2. Declaration of 01 new Natural Monument. 3. Declaration of 06 new Wildlife Reserves. 4. Proposal for the expansion of 08 National Parks. 5. Extension of 01 Natural Monument. 6. Declaration of 01 Biosphere Reserve. 7. Preparation of 03 Management Plans and Use Regulations. 8. Updating of 04 Management Plans and Use Regulations.” (p. 145)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Carry out training workshops on the conservation of biological diversity with a focus on Adaptation and Mitigation to Climate Change for the period 2021 - 2030.” Description: “Carry out nine (09) training workshops on the conservation of biological diversity with a focus on Adaptation and Mitigation of Climate Change, estimating during this period to train a total of 450 people, including officials, communities, students and teachers.” (p. 149)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Strengthening the organization of environmental laboratories: Strengthening the capacities of the laboratory staff in the analytical, instrumental, statistical, environmental management and adaptation to climate change areas in order to use the latest technology recommended methodologies to execute with greater precision and accuracy of the physicochemical and bacteriological analyzes as support in the management of monitoring and evaluation of the effects of the change in the bodies of water.” (p. 136-137)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Design sustainable socio-productive training programs, using information and communication technologies to facilitate their continuous dissemination.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Incorporate young people who complete specialized training to the youth brigades.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Train workers who will assume the role of information multipliers” (p. 135)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Water, Sowing and Harvesting Water: “The UNESCO International Hydrological Program in Venezuela will be implemented, whose purpose is research on water, management, education and capacity building in water resources in the face of the effects of Climate Change” (p. 103)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Science and Technology: “The vulnerability maps of the country will be prepared to prioritize the adaptation strategy in the different sectors.” (p. 109)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Health: “Evaluation of entomological risk and impact on vector control in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Gender (Rural Women): “Reduction of vulnerability to the effects of climate change and increased resilience of rural women” (p. 119-120). Action Description: “Agreement with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), to develop the project ‘Reducing vulnerability due to climate change effects and increasing the resilience of rural women’, with the aim of increasing the resilience capacities of rural women, producers and organizations to face climate change through the implementation of sustainable and gender-sensitive socio-productive strategies, in the states of Mérida, Trujillo and Portuguesa. Likewise, the training that the project will carry out for women agricultural producers and their organizations will favor in them the knowledge and exercise of their rights, and the development of their leadership and oversight in relation to the management of gender-sensitive agroclimatic risk by the State. In 2021, it is estimated to benefit a total of 1,500 rural women and 150 agricultural organizations. To date, it has been possible to identify gender-sensitive needs, capacities, roles and actions to be carried out in the field of disaster risk management and agroclimatic with rural women producers.” (p. 120)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Set up youth brigades for risk management, taking into account the division of the integral development regions.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Specialize the youth brigades in attention to the possible geographic vulnerabilities of each integral region.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Form the regional youth brigades for the three moments of risk management: before-during-after the occurrence of the natural phenomenon.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Youth: “Create the Chapter on Climate Change and Risk Management in the framework of the Youth Congress 2022, in order to show the progress of the regional organization.” (p. 122)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Water, Integral Transformation of the Management Model: “292 experiences of revolutionary transfer of service to the organized community will be consolidated for the rational use of water resources and respond to natural or anthropic threats that may arise at the national level due to the effects of climate vulnerability” (p. 103)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Water, Comprehensive Security of the National Water System: “The Plan for water resilience and mitigation of the negative effects of Climate Change of waters on the population and their assets will be developed.” (p. 102)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “National Water Quality Information System: The National Water Quality Information System (SNICA) will be reviewed and put into operation (the software) for the incorporation of the analytical data obtained in each of the hydrographic basins that are included in the annual monitoring program in order to calculate the Water Quality Index and to determine the degree of variation of those parameters interrelated with the effects of climate change.” (p. 138)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Water Quality Indicator: The Water Quality Indicator and the calculations for determining the deviation of the parameters interrelated with the effects of climate change, will be constructed according to the historical data of the hydrographic basins included in the water quality monitoring program, which will provide relevant information for adaptation and generate mitigation policies to reduce the adverse effects of climate change.” (p. 138-139)

name: Cross-Cutting Area
title: Water, Strengthening of the National Water System: “There will be a Regional Financing Fund for scientific research and construction of parts and pieces to strengthen the National Water System to attend to emergencies that may arise due to hydrometeorological events.” (p. 102)

name: Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
title: Water, Comprehensive Security of the National Water System: “There will be an Early Warning Communication Network for natural or man-made threats that may arise at the national level due to the effects of climate vulnerability.” (p. 102)

name: Economy-wide
title: Mining: “The emissions generated by the activity from 2020 to 2030 will be estimated to determine the area to be restored and the hectares affected by the mining activity will be conditioned annually.” (p. 124)

name: Education
title: Basic Education: “The formation of the Ecological Brigades in all the educational institutions of the country is estimated.” (p. 113)

name: Education
title: Basic Education: “The strengthening of the “Bicentennial Forest” Program is estimated with the planting of new tree species in coordination with different national, state, municipal and community entities.” (p. 113)

name: Education
title: University Education, National Convention for Environmental Studies (CONEA) Bolivarian University of Venezuela: “Activities at the institutional and community level, participates and encourages: 1) 10 community forums and community organization strategies will be developed in order to inform and raise awareness about the effects of Climate Change. 2) There will be 10 exchanges of experiences and presentation of innovation and presentations that will be based on research that contributes to the adaptation-mitigation of Climate Change with transformation through education.” (p. 116)

name: Education
title: University Education, National Convention for Environmental Studies (CONEA) Bolivarian University of Venezuela: “University Company Bolivarian Laboratory of Innovation for Food, Environment, Nutrition and Health (Labinnovans), S.A. Labinnovans: 5 services of laboratory analysis and environmental impact evaluations of activities capable of degrading the environment will be carried out, which will allow the strengthening of the different careers, through the environmental studies center, providing support to the academic development of the students.” (p. 116)

name: Education
title: University Education, Rafael María Baralt National Experimental University (UNERMB) - Research Program -CDCHT: “Research and innovation policies at UNERMB together with the Research Center for the Promotion of Endogenous Development (CIPDE) and the Center for Agrifood and Environmental Research (CIAGROA): 1) 17 lines, research and innovation projects will be developed that have sustainability as an objective to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change; 2) 22 Environmental Brigades will be implemented in university spaces, estimating 1 for each undergraduate and graduate campus to raise awareness about the effects of Climate Change. 3) 50 (Popular Power Base Organizations) afforestation activities will be developed in conjunction with the Tree Mission to form optimal areas for carbon sinks. 4) 1250 sustainability areas will be formed for students, teaching staff, administrative staff and workers of our institution to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change. 5) 2,400 areas of sustainability will be formed for grassroots organizations of popular power to guarantee food security that is threatened by the adverse effects of Climate Change. 6) 120 Sustainable Development Training Seminar and the 2030 agenda "Transform Our World" will be held. Dictated by the Research Center for the Promotion of Endogenous Development (CIPDE).” (p. 116-117)

name: Education
title: University Education: “The Venezuelan Hydrocarbons University (UVH) has a Master's program in Ecology and Hydrocarbons in relation to Climate Change, and a subprogram with the ‘Project for Evaluation and Estimation of Greenhouse Gases in oil installations.’ 3 degree projects will be developed within the central research line Impact of the Hydrocarbons Industry and its Socio-environmental Implications on Venezuelan Ecological Systems.” (p. 117)

name: Education
title: Communes (Popular Organization): “For the year 2030, the scope of the following is planned: 50,000 registered Communal Councils, 10,000 registered Communes, more than 2,700 organized Social Movements and more than 2,000 Social Battle Rooms, in order to raise awareness and contribute to the construction of actions in adaptation-mitigation of Climate Change with transformation through education.” (p. 110)

name: Education
title: Youth: “Prepare communication plans where information is provided on the structure, operation and location of the Brigades and the dissemination of sustainable youth policies and educational campaigns.” (p. 122)

name: Education
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Design and implement an information and orientation campaign for workers of the MPPPPST and its attached entities on the emission of greenhouse gases, Determined National Contributions (NDC), and mitigation and adaptation to climate change.” (p. 135)

name: Education
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Design and implement an information campaign directed to the Work Entities, and their organizations, on the emission of greenhouse gases, the Determined National Contributions (NDC), and the mitigation and adaptation to climate change.” (p. 135)

name: Education
title: Water, Education, Technological Innovation and Productive Chain: “100% of the Basic Schools will be addressed with the "Water in our Lives" Program and other educational programs to sensitize children about water resources.” (p. 103)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Review and update of the Draft National Land Use Plan - PNOT.” Description: “The National Spatial Planning Plan - PNOT is a territorial management instrument that must be reviewed according to two basic criteria, the first referring to the fulfillment of its planning horizon, which is long-term (20 years); a second case is related to the change of government, in the terms provided and established in the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. In any case, for both situations the following is required: 1. The formation of the National Land Management Commission, chaired by the Ministry of People's Power for Planning, with the Technical Secretariat under the responsibility of the Ministry of People's Power for Ecosocialism. 2. Formation of inter-institutional working groups and assignment of responsibilities. 3. Generation of a methodological process to carry out the review and update of the basic thematic documents and for the collective construction of the proposals.” (p. 143)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Plan for the Planning and Integrated Management of Coastal Zones (POGIZC) of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.” Description: “Within the framework of the approval of the Plan for the Integrated Management and Planning of Coastal Zones (POGIZC) of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and the continuity of activities linked to the 10 Programs for the Integrated Management of Coastal Zones, the aspiration is to in the period 2021 - 2030: 1. Review and update the Conservation and Sustainable Development Policies of the Coastal Zones of Venezuela. 2. Continue the strengthening of the System of Marine-Coastal Protected Areas of Venezuela by creating and improving the processes of planning and integrated management of their territories. 3. Continue and strengthen the Inventory and Characterization of the Sandy Beaches of Venezuela. 4. Continue the reactivation and participation in various spaces for the creation of Alliances: Redparques, Ramsar Convention, UNDP, UNEP, WCPA, GEF, PPD, Inparques, Mintur, Alianza de Montañas (FAO), Andean Mountain Initiative, among others. 5. Strengthening and systematization of the knowledge base, and of the Information Systems for the Integrated Management of Coastal Zones (SIGIZC).” (p. 144)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Orinoco Oil Belt Territory Planning Project "Hugo Chávez Frías" (National Strategic Development Zone - ZDEN).” Description: “For the purposes of approval and subsequent execution of the activities identified in the instrument, the following is required: 1. Call for the Public Consultation Process. 2. Holding of Public Consultation Workshops. 3. Evaluation of the proposals and subsequent incorporation in the Draft Decree. 4. Presentation of the Draft Decree for approval by the President of the Republic in the Council of Ministers.” (p. 144-145)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Areas Under the Special Administration Regime (ABRAE) and their Plans of Ordinance and Use Regulations (PORU).” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030 it is estimated to continue strengthening the set of Areas Under Special Administration Regime (ABRAE) of Venezuela, as part of the agreements and commitments assumed before the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) and the Framework Convention of the United Nations on Climate Change. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Declaration of 03 new National Parks. 2. Declaration of 01 new Natural Monument. 3. Declaration of 06 new Wildlife Reserves. 4. Proposal for the expansion of 08 National Parks. 5. Extension of 01 Natural Monument. 6. Declaration of 01 Biosphere Reserve. 7. Preparation of 03 Management Plans and Use Regulations. 8. Updating of 04 Management Plans and Use Regulations.” (p. 145)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “State Plans for Land Use Planning.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030, it is estimated to continue strengthening the instruments for spatial planning at the state level. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Strengthening the State Territory Planning Commissions. 2. Promote the development of the Territorial Planning Plans of the States Amazonas, La Guaira, Lara and Sucre. 3. Support the updating of the Territorial Planning Plans of the States of Carabobo, Falcón and Monagas. 4. Coordinate the development of the Orinoco Mining Arc Territory Planning Plan (National Strategic Development Zone).” (p. 146)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Soil Conservation, Desertification and Drought.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030 it is estimated to continue developing actions in the National Action Program to Combat Desertification and Drought Mitigation. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Construction of the Country Report for 2022. 2. Promote local initiatives related to the Fight against Desertification and Drought Mitigation. 3. Promote the review and update of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, target 15.3, its Indicator 15.3.1 “Proportion of degraded land in relation to the total land area”, with its three sub-indicators 1) Land Cover (Trends in land use / land cover); 2) Land Productivity (Land Productivity Trend); and 3) Soil Organic Carbon (Carbon pool on the surface and in the soil). Establishing the Working Group for the Neutrality of Land Degradation (NDT), which with the participation of researchers, academics and other key actors was validated” (p. 146)

name: Environment
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “National Policies for the Conservation and Sustainable Development of Coastal Zones.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030, it is estimated that the Conservation and Sustainable Development Policies of the Coastal Zones of Venezuela will be reviewed and updated, considering, among others, the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the United Nations Framework Convention on the Climate Change, as well as the guidelines on the United Nations Decade on Ecosystem Restoration and the United Nations Decade of Ocean Sciences for Sustainable Development, for which the following will be required: 1. The reactivation of the Working Committee Central of the Coastal Zones (CTCZC), chaired by the Ministry of Popular Power for Ecososcialism. 2. The reactivation and strengthening of the Coastal Zones Work Committees at the State Level (CTZCNE). 3. Generation of a methodological process to carry out the review and update of the National Policies for Conservation and Sustainable Development of Coastal Zones.” (p. 147)

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Carry out training workshops on the conservation of biological diversity with a focus on Adaptation and Mitigation to Climate Change for the period 2021 - 2030.” Description: “Carry out nine (09) training workshops on the conservation of biological diversity with a focus on Adaptation and Mitigation of Climate Change, estimating during this period to train a total of 450 people, including officials, communities, students and teachers.” (p. 149)

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Strengthen the Program for the Release of specimens of threatened or endangered species.” Description: “Carry out the release of 300,000 specimens of threatened or endangered wild species, as part of the National Program for the Conservation of Threatened Species.” (p. 150)

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Installation and operation of ex situ conservation centers for threatened or endangered species.” Description: “Install and operate six (06) ex situ conservation centers for specimens of threatened or endangered wild species, as part of the National Program for the Conservation of Threatened Species.” (p. 150)

name: Environment
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Restoration of wetlands sensitive to the effects of climate change.” Description: “Carry out the restoration of two (02) degraded wetlands (mangrove and morichal ecosystems), such as strategic areas for the conservation of biological diversity.” (p. 151)

name: Environment
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Continuous monitoring and evaluation of water quality: The Network of Environmental Laboratories, designs a project to strengthen the analytical capacity of laboratories, at the national level in order to provide them with scientific equipment, materials, reagents and staff training with the objective of generating information on the quality of water, which allows informing the general public, as well as support for formulating management policies that allow adaptation to the changes suffered due to Climate Change.” (p. 136)

name: Environment
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Strengthening the organization of environmental laboratories: Strengthening the capacities of the laboratory staff in the analytical, instrumental, statistical, environmental management and adaptation to climate change areas in order to use the latest technology recommended methodologies to execute with greater precision and accuracy of the physicochemical and bacteriological analyzes as support in the management of monitoring and evaluation of the effects of the change in the bodies of water.” (p. 136-137)

name: Environment
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Awareness, communication and dissemination of water management: The strengthening of awareness, communication and dissemination activities, through newsletters, mass media such as: written press, television, radio, social networks and other alternative media, that will inform the popular power and other organizations of the actions that are carried out related to adaptation to climate change and of the ways in which popular power can contribute to the conservation and preservation of water in order to reduce the adverse effects of climate change .” (p. 137)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthening of entomological surveillance and vector control at the national level in the face of climate change.” (p. 131)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthen the information system for entomological surveillance and vector control at the national level in the face of climate change, with the design and implementation of information and georeferencing systems.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Train professional and technical health personnel, ASICs, organized community and governmental and non-governmental organizations, in entomological surveillance actions and vector control measures within the framework of the integrated management of vector control at the national level in the face of change climate.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthen basic response capacities in entomological surveillance and vector control within the framework of integrated vector control management at the national level in the face of climate change with the updating of the methodological framework, supply of materials and supplies, ecological characterization and correlation of environmental variables (temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, among others) and supervision of surveillance and control activities.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Evaluation of entomological risk and impact on vector control in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthening the surveillance and sanitary control of water quality at the national level in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthening of sanitary surveillance and control of supply systems (water sources, treatment and distribution system) and monitoring of water quality in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Train professional and technical health personnel, ASICs, organized community, and governmental and non-governmental organizations, in surveillance actions and safety plans for climate-resilient drinking water at the national level.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthen the national water quality health surveillance information system, associated with climate change, with the design and implementation of information and georeferencing systems.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Risk and impact assessment in the control of water quality in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthening of the surveillance and sanitary control of air quality, in fixed sources (incinerators of the health sector).” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Strengthening of the surveillance and sanitary control of air quality, in fixed sources (incinerators of the health sector), through identification of national censuses, in order to know the conditions and establish technical guidelines on the best ways to reduce gas emissions greenhouse effect in the health sector.” (p. 132)

name: Health
title: Health: “Train professional and technical personnel of the health sector, in the actions of surveillance and sanitary control of fixed sources (incinerators)” (p. 132)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Mining: “Projects will be selected for the remediation of 1,575 hectares affected by mining activity, reducing erosion and carrying sediment to river beds.” (p. 124)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Mining: “The remediation of 1,575 affected hectares is estimated with 48,375 native trees being planted in the areas affected by mining.” (p. 124)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Mining: “The carbon sequestration per year from 2020 to 2030 by reforestation of mature forests will be quantified.” (p. 124)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “State Plans for Land Use Planning.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030, it is estimated to continue strengthening the instruments for spatial planning at the state level. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Strengthening the State Territory Planning Commissions. 2. Promote the development of the Territorial Planning Plans of the States Amazonas, La Guaira, Lara and Sucre. 3. Support the updating of the Territorial Planning Plans of the States of Carabobo, Falcón and Monagas. 4. Coordinate the development of the Orinoco Mining Arc Territory Planning Plan (National Strategic Development Zone).” (p. 146)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Ecosystems (Coastal Zone, Territorial Planning, Mountains, Wetlands): “Soil Conservation, Desertification and Drought.” Description: “During the period 2021 - 2030 it is estimated to continue developing actions in the National Action Program to Combat Desertification and Drought Mitigation. for which it is estimated to work on: 1. Construction of the Country Report for 2022. 2. Promote local initiatives related to the Fight against Desertification and Drought Mitigation. 3. Promote the review and update of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, target 15.3, its Indicator 15.3.1 “Proportion of degraded land in relation to the total land area”, with its three sub-indicators 1) Land Cover (Trends in land use / land cover); 2) Land Productivity (Land Productivity Trend); and 3) Soil Organic Carbon (Carbon pool on the surface and in the soil). Establishing the Working Group for the Neutrality of Land Degradation (NDT), which with the participation of researchers, academics and other key actors was validated” (p. 146)

name: LULUCF/Forestry
title: Biodiversity (Conservation and Use of Sustainable Biodiversity): “Restoration of wetlands sensitive to the effects of climate change.” Description: “Carry out the restoration of two (02) degraded wetlands (mangrove and morichal ecosystems), such as strategic areas for the conservation of biological diversity.” (p. 151)

name: Social Development
title: Gender: “‘Conuqueras Women’ Program: Its purpose is to include women in the productive agri-food sector, having as a vision the development of sustainable agricultural activity. This program seeks the empowerment of rural women and the recognition of their ancestral knowledge as a basis for the transversality of gender equity and equality in everything related to the agricultural sector and public policies, based on the recognition of rural women's rights. During 2021, priority has been given to the management of land tenure as property for rural women and conuqueras. In this sense: 1) It is proposed to progressively serve 5,141 women in order to guarantee their equal access to land ownership and combat the existing gap. In agreement with the National Land Institute, in a first stage, the direct adjudication of rural land titles to 477 women farmers at the national level, equivalent to 7,400,304 hectares, was achieved. 2) In the second stage, it is planned to incorporate the beneficiaries into the Conuquera Women Program for the production of 22,357 tons of different agricultural items nationwide.” (p. 119)

name: Social Development
title: Gender (Rural Women): “Reduction of vulnerability to the effects of climate change and increased resilience of rural women” (p. 119-120). Action Description: “Agreement with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), to develop the project ‘Reducing vulnerability due to climate change effects and increasing the resilience of rural women’, with the aim of increasing the resilience capacities of rural women, producers and organizations to face climate change through the implementation of sustainable and gender-sensitive socio-productive strategies, in the states of Mérida, Trujillo and Portuguesa. Likewise, the training that the project will carry out for women agricultural producers and their organizations will favor in them the knowledge and exercise of their rights, and the development of their leadership and oversight in relation to the management of gender-sensitive agroclimatic risk by the State. In 2021, it is estimated to benefit a total of 1,500 rural women and 150 agricultural organizations. To date, it has been possible to identify gender-sensitive needs, capacities, roles and actions to be carried out in the field of disaster risk management and agroclimatic with rural women producers.” (p. 120)

name: Social Development
title: Indigenous Peoples: “Comprehensive care for the indigenous population in a vulnerable condition settled in the national territory, promoting the eradication of extreme poverty.” (p. 127)

name: Social Development
title: Indigenous Peoples: “Comprehensive care for the indigenous population in a vulnerable condition settled in the national territory, promoting the eradication of extreme poverty.” (p. 128)

name: Social Development
title: Communes (Popular Organization): “For the year 2030, the scope of the following is planned: 50,000 registered Communal Councils, 10,000 registered Communes, more than 2,700 organized Social Movements and more than 2,000 Social Battle Rooms, in order to raise awareness and contribute to the construction of actions in adaptation-mitigation of Climate Change with transformation through education.” (p. 110)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Set up youth brigades for risk management, taking into account the division of the integral development regions.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Specialize the youth brigades in attention to the possible geographic vulnerabilities of each integral region.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Form the regional youth brigades for the three moments of risk management: before-during-after the occurrence of the natural phenomenon.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Design sustainable socio-productive training programs, using information and communication technologies to facilitate their continuous dissemination.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Incorporate young people who complete specialized training to the youth brigades.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Create the Chapter on Climate Change and Risk Management in the framework of the Youth Congress 2022, in order to show the progress of the regional organization.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Prepare communication plans where information is provided on the structure, operation and location of the Brigades and the dissemination of sustainable youth policies and educational campaigns.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Youth: “Make alliances with public and private institutions for the consolidation of the aforementioned actions.” (p. 122)

name: Social Development
title: Labor (Social Justice): “An Action Plan will be designed and implemented with the aim of informing and guiding workers about their participation and role in mitigating and adapting to climate change, as multiplying subjects in the social work process, their family and community environment. for the empowerment of climate action.” (p. 134-135)

name: Social Development
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Carry out coordination between the Ministry of People's Power for the Social Work Process and the Ministry of People's Power for Ecosocialism to implement the information and guidance aimed at workers” (p. 135)

name: Social Development
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Design and implement an information and orientation campaign for workers of the MPPPPST and its attached entities on the emission of greenhouse gases, Determined National Contributions (NDC), and mitigation and adaptation to climate change.” (p. 135)

name: Social Development
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Design and implement an information campaign directed to the Work Entities, and their organizations, on the emission of greenhouse gases, the Determined National Contributions (NDC), and the mitigation and adaptation to climate change.” (p. 135)

name: Social Development
title: Labor (Social Justice): “Train workers who will assume the role of information multipliers” (p. 135)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “It is estimated 5,700,000 homes to be built in response to the need for housing of the Venezuelan people, of which a % will be destined as a response to people who are affected by the effects of Climate Change.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “It is estimated that 700,000 houses will be built with alternative bioconstructive systems (wood, bamboo, bahareque), in response to losses and damages due to adverse effects of Climate Change, and to special attention to rural areas, indigenous peoples and other ecologically fragile areas.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “The construction of 1,140,000 homes is estimated using locally produced materials, in order to reduce the emission of polluting gases into the atmosphere from transportation by 20%.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “It is estimated to improve 6 current housing construction standards for the integration of natural climate variability.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “It is estimated that 108 days of arborization will be organized, aimed at increasing the green areas of urban planning, at the national level to minimize the effects of Climate Change.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “2 sectoral plans and 9 annual plans will be developed in the habitat and housing sector, aimed at establishing the sustainability policies necessary to mitigate risks from hydro-meteorological hazards and direct the construction of houses that guarantee climate resilience.” (p. 106)

name: Urban
title: Urban Settlements (Housing): “4 particular plans will be developed in the habitat and housing sector, namely: Local Strategic Development Plan (PDEL), as a fundamental tool to guarantee the right to the city and harmony with the habitat, allowing the orderly intervention of human settlements from the local point of view, Comprehensive maintenance plan for residential buildings, aimed at mitigating 30% of polluting elements in existing buildings, Solid waste management pilot plan, aimed at reducing 40% of solid waste that is inserted into the habitat, and the Urban Forest Plan, to promote the reintegration of plant and animal species into the territory that was intervened.” (p. 106)

name: Water
title: Water, Integral Transformation of the Management Model: “292 experiences of revolutionary transfer of service to the organized community will be consolidated for the rational use of water resources and respond to natural or anthropic threats that may arise at the national level due to the effects of climate vulnerability” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Water, Strengthening of the National Water System: “The 118 desalination plants installed in the country will be 100% operational as an action to guarantee the supply of water resources to the most vulnerable populations.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Comprehensive Security of the National Water System: “Four levels will be installed for the physical security of the National Water System facilities, together with the organized people and the State security bodies to guarantee the supply of water resources to the most vulnerable populations.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Awareness, communication and dissemination of water management: The strengthening of awareness, communication and dissemination activities, through newsletters, mass media such as: written press, television, radio, social networks and other alternative media, that will inform the popular power and other organizations of the actions that are carried out related to adaptation to climate change and of the ways in which popular power can contribute to the conservation and preservation of water in order to reduce the adverse effects of climate change .” (p. 137)

name: Water
title: Water, Popular Government of the Waters: “20,000 Technical Water Tables will be consolidated in the country for the organization and awareness of the population for the rational use of water resources in the face of the effects of Climate Change.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Popular Government of the Waters: “800 Community Water Management Rooms will be installed to sensitize the population for the rational use of water resources from the perspective of resilience to the effects of Climate Change.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Popular Government of the Waters: “There will be a new Organic Law for Waters in order to achieve a sustainable future and the management of water resources from the perspective of resilience to the effects of climate change.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Strengthening of the National Water System: “The 6,218 solutions identified in the Map of Solutions for the National Water System will be implemented in response to the population affected by hydrometeorological events.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Strengthening of the National Water System: “There will be a National System for Comprehensive Water Management to identify future demand for decision-making regarding the distribution of water resources among the different possible uses of water.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Education, Technological Innovation and Productive Chain: “The operations of the National Water Industry (INASA) will be consolidated in order to guarantee endogenous knowledge and techniques in the treatment, purification and distribution of water resources to the most vulnerable populations.” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Water, Education, Technological Innovation and Productive Chain: “There will be an application to monitor and control the execution of the Map of Solutions, service incidents and registration of Technical Water Tables for comprehensive management of water resources.” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Water, Sowing and Harvesting Water: “The National Fund for Comprehensive Water Management (FONAGUAS) will be consolidated in order to distribute the water resource among the different possible uses of water.” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Health: “Train professional and technical health personnel, ASICs, organized community, and governmental and non-governmental organizations, in surveillance actions and safety plans for climate-resilient drinking water at the national level.” (p. 132)

name: Water
title: Health: “Strengthen the national water quality health surveillance information system, associated with climate change, with the design and implementation of information and georeferencing systems.” (p. 132)

name: Water
title: Health: “Risk and impact assessment in the control of water quality in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Water
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Continuous monitoring and evaluation of water quality: The Network of Environmental Laboratories, designs a project to strengthen the analytical capacity of laboratories, at the national level in order to provide them with scientific equipment, materials, reagents and staff training with the objective of generating information on the quality of water, which allows informing the general public, as well as support for formulating management policies that allow adaptation to the changes suffered due to Climate Change.” (p. 136)

name: Water
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “National Water Quality Information System: The National Water Quality Information System (SNICA) will be reviewed and put into operation (the software) for the incorporation of the analytical data obtained in each of the hydrographic basins that are included in the annual monitoring program in order to calculate the Water Quality Index and to determine the degree of variation of those parameters interrelated with the effects of climate change.” (p. 138)

name: Water
title: Environmental Quality Management (Water Quality Monitoring – Environmental Laboratories): “Water Quality Indicator: The Water Quality Indicator and the calculations for determining the deviation of the parameters interrelated with the effects of climate change, will be constructed according to the historical data of the hydrographic basins included in the water quality monitoring program, which will provide relevant information for adaptation and generate mitigation policies to reduce the adverse effects of climate change.” (p. 138-139)

name: Water
title: Health: “Strengthening the surveillance and sanitary control of water quality at the national level in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Water
title: Health: “Strengthening of sanitary surveillance and control of supply systems (water sources, treatment and distribution system) and monitoring of water quality in the face of climate change.” (p. 132)

name: Water
title: Water, Popular Government of the Waters: “1,736 Brigades of the Popular Power for Water (BRIPPAS) will be formed to repair minor breakdowns and guarantee water to the population.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Sowing and Harvesting Water: “The maintenance of the 104 reservoirs in the country will be rehabilitated and stabilized to guarantee the optimal supply of water resources.” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Water, Strengthening of the National Water System: “There will be a Regional Financing Fund for scientific research and construction of parts and pieces to strengthen the National Water System to attend to emergencies that may arise due to hydrometeorological events.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Comprehensive Security of the National Water System: “The Plan for water resilience and mitigation of the negative effects of Climate Change of waters on the population and their assets will be developed.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Comprehensive Security of the National Water System: “There will be an Early Warning Communication Network for natural or man-made threats that may arise at the national level due to the effects of climate vulnerability.” (p. 102)

name: Water
title: Water, Education, Technological Innovation and Productive Chain: “100% of the Basic Schools will be addressed with the "Water in our Lives" Program and other educational programs to sensitize children about water resources.” (p. 103)

name: Water
title: Water, Sowing and Harvesting Water: “The UNESCO International Hydrological Program in Venezuela will be implemented, whose purpose is research on water, management, education and capacity building in water resources in the face of the effects of Climate Change” (p. 103)
